ParentCompanyName: Hillshire Brands,a subsidiary of Tyson Foods

_prev_prog_3.Description: This facility was built in 1999, since it is a relatively new facility, it was designed to detect ammonia at low levels and is monitored through a computerized monitoring system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

TYSON FOODS, INC - St Joseph Plant, St Joseph, MO

1.    Accident Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Policy

Tyson Foods, Inc. St Joseph Plant facility management shall implement the requirements of this Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68 and with the corresponding regulations under OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to Tyson Foods, Inc. employees, the public and the environment.  This objective will be accomplished by utilizing standardized operating procedures, training for employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers.  This plan covers all Tyson Foods, Inc. owned activities at this facility.  Tyson Foods, Inc. management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this plan.

2.    Facility Description

Tyson Foods, Inc. operates a prepared foods processing facility at this location.  Packaged beef, chicken, turkey and ham is trucked in and processed into hot dogs, sliced deli and sausage. 

Several chemicals are used on-site, but only one (Anhydrous Ammonia) that exceeds the threshold quantity for the Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68).   Ammonia is used as a refrigerant and is located throughout the facility. 

3.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps.

The St Joseph Plant facility is governed by a set of OSHA and USEPA regulations that require planning and facility activities intended to prevent releases of hazardous materials, or if a release inadvertently occurs, to minimize the consequences of a release to employees of the facility, the public and the environment.

These regulations include but are not limited to:

?    40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention

?    40 CFR Part

112, Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure

?    40 CFR Part 264, Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan

?    29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management

?    40 CFR Part 302, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)

The key concepts in the Tyson Foods, Inc. release prevention program are employee participation, appropriate design and maintenance of equipment, and appropriate training of all employees.  Tyson Foods, Inc. has developed and documented these elements in their process safety management program (PSM).  Employee participation in the release-prevention program is encouraged and supported by Tyson Foods, Inc. management.   Key personnel are responsible for conducting process hazard analyses (PHA) and implementing the findings from these analyses for the ammonia system.   Tyson Foods, Inc. programs ensure process safety are integrated in all aspects of operation beginning with construction and installation of new equipment, systems, and facilities, maintenance of these systems and changes to these systems. Tyson Foods, Inc. maintains documentation of maintenance activities to ensure that key systems are maintained appropriately to minimize the risk of a release.  Tyson Foods, Inc. is committed to providing appropriate training to all employees regarding safety procedures.   Each new employee is provided comprehensive operations and safety training during their initial orientation to the facility for their job duties.  In addition, Tyson Foods, Inc. conducts regularly scheduled safety training for all employees each year.  Additional training is provided to maintenance personnel related to the system for which they are responsible.  This includes PPE training and qualification. 

4.    Five Year Accident History

The St Joseph, Missouri facility has not experienced any accidental releases resulting in injury in the past five years. 

5.    Emergency Response Program

Tyson Foods, Inc. St Joseph Plant facility maintains an onsite hazmat team.  The ERP h

as been coordinated with the local fire department as the primary responders for all emergencies at the facility.  

6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Tyson Foods, Inc. completes a thorough review of the ammonia system each time a design change is implemented.  A Tyson food, Inc. is committed to using these methods to identify and implement ways to improve the safety of this system.
